title: 112_hr2160
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Jobs Through Environmental Safeguarding and Streamlining Act of 2011" and includes provisions for the advanced acquisition of real property. SEC. 2 amends Section 108 of title 23, United States Code, allowing the Secretary to encourage the acquisition of transportation rights-of-way for long-range needs. SEC. 3 focuses on efficient environmental reviews for project decision-making. (a) Programmatic Compliance.--Section 139(b) of title 23, United States Code, is amended to allow for programmatic approaches and strategies in environmental programs and permits. 
(b) Designation of DOT Modal Administration To Serve as Lead Agency.--Section 139(c)(1) of such title is amended to designate a single modal administration of the Department of Transportation as the lead agency. 
(c) Project Initiation.--Section 139(e) of such title is amended to provide flexibility for project sponsors to satisfy project initiation requirements. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to various sections of title 23, United States Code, related to environmental impact statements, coordination plans, and guidelines for projects under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The amendments include requirements for project sponsors to submit draft notices for publication, expanding the scope of projects covered, and issuing guidelines to assist States and local entities in assuming a greater role in preparing environmental documents. The curr_chunk discusses guidelines for projects under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969, including a list of State reports that can be used, specifying the extent of State or local government participation without federal court jurisdiction. Additionally, there is a provision for the Secretary to conduct a study on reciprocity agreements. The Secretary will conduct a study on reciprocity agreements with States to enhance State involvement in the environmental review process for projects and expedite project delivery. A report on the study results will be submitted to relevant Congressional committees. SEC. 4. SURFACE TRANSPORTATION PROJECT DELIVERY PROGRAM. Amendment to title 23, United States Code, regarding responsibility for conformity determinations under the Clean Air Act for highway projects involving multiple modal administrations. The Secretary determines a project as a 'highway project' if the Federal Highway Administration leads it. For projects involving the Federal Highway Administration and another modal administration, State authorities may include those related to both administrations. The Secretary may permit states meeting selection criteria to participate in the program without requiring an application. The Secretary may allow states to join the program without an application. A written agreement must be signed by the Governor or top transportation official, in which the state agrees to assume some of the Secretary's responsibilities and use the best available science. The state must consent to federal court jurisdiction for compliance with the Secretary's responsibilities and certify that state laws are in place to carry out the assumed responsibilities. The state must agree to federal court oversight and certify state laws for assumed responsibilities. Written agreements with states can exclude certain projects, have a maximum 5-year term, and be renewable. The written agreement with a state under this section may not impose limitations on project delivery methods not otherwise applicable to the state. Audits and monitoring procedures are also amended under this title. The program allows the Secretary to monitor a State's compliance with a written agreement instead of conducting audits after 10 consecutive years of participation. If the State repeatedly fails to comply during monitoring, audits will be initiated. The Secretary will establish procedures for monitoring. The Jobs Through Environmental Safeguarding and Streamlining Act of 2011 amends Section 327(h) to require the Secretary to report to Congress every 4 years on the program's results. The report must be made public and submitted to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The report must include assessments on reduced delays, enhanced project delivery, cost savings, environmental protection, and recommendations for program improvements. The elimination of the termination date for an environmental document quality control program in transportation departments of participating states.
